title: Legislative Council Question No.5 (Oral Reply)
question_text:
Date of Sitting: 13 December 2000 Asked by: Hon LEUNG Yiu-chung
Replied by: Secretary for Health and Welfare   Question : Regarding the existing policy whereby elderly recipients of the disability allowance are not eligible for the old age allowance, will the Government inform this Council: (a) of the rationale for implementing such a policy; (b) whether the Equal Opportunities Commission ("EOC") has been consulted to ascertain if such a

Opportunities Commission ("EOC") has been consulted to ascertain if such a
policy contravenes the provisions in the Disability Discrimination Ordinance; if so, of
the outcome of the consultation; if not, the reasons for that; and whether it knows the
EOC's specific stance on the policy; and (c) of the number of
elderly persons who received the disability allowance and, among them, the respective
numbers of those who were not allowed to apply for the normal or higher old age allowance
because they had been granted the disability allowance, in each of the past two years; as

because they had been granted the disability allowance, in each of the past two years; as
well as the annual amount of old age allowance required to be paid out if these persons
were granted the allowance?
reply_text:
Madam President, In reply to the question
raised by the Honourable LEUNG Yiu-chung on the policy that Disability Allowance (DA)
recipients are not eligible for the Old Age Allowance (OAA), I would like to offer my
explanations as follows : (a) The Social Security
Allowance (SSA) Scheme, which comprises two components, namely the OAA and DA, was
established in 1973 and was formerly known as the Disability and Infirmity Allowance
Scheme. Because the severely disabled and the elderly infirm were considered to have extra

Scheme. Because the severely disabled and the elderly infirm were considered to have extra
needs, the original objectives of the scheme were to give some financial help to the
families concerned and to reduce demand for institutional care for these two groups. At that time, an
applicant was considered severely disabled if he was certified by the then Director of
Medical and Health Services as being in a position broadly equivalent to a person with a
100% loss of earning capacity according to the criteria in the First Schedule of the then
Workmen’s Compensation Scheme (now Employees’ Compensation Ordinance) (Cap 282).

Workmen’s Compensation Scheme (now Employees’ Compensation Ordinance) (Cap 282).
On the other hand, an applicant aged 75 or above would be eligible for the then infirmity
allowance. As the extra needs of an infirm person are generally fewer than those of a
severely disabled person, the Infirmity Allowance was fixed, as a matter of administrative
convenience, at 50% of the Disability Allowance. In this regard, the mutually exclusive
arrangement of the OAA and DA was based on the fact that no one would incur more than 100%

loss of earning capacity. As two components of one
single scheme catering for two different groups, it has always been the policy that anyone
can choose to apply for either of the two benefits, but not both. This is to avoid paying
double benefits to an individual.  (b) The Equal Opportunity
Commission (EOC) has approached the Social Welfare Department (SWD) in mid November and
the SWD has already provided the EOC with the requested information. The EOC has not yet
made known their stance on the issue to us. We have sought legal opinion which has

made known their stance on the issue to us. We have sought legal opinion which has
confirmed that the existing policy of DA recipients not eligible for OAA does not
contravene the provisions of the Disability Discrimination Ordinance. (c) The information on
the number of DA recipients of 65 or above is : <u></u> <u>As at 3/1999</u> <u>As at 3/2000</u> DA recipients of 65 or above 32 195 35 528 SWD has not maintained

record on those DA recipients who have tried to apply for OAA in parallel. In fact, it has
been stated clearly in SWD’s publicity pamphlets on the SSA that applicants are not
eligible for receiving both allowances at the same time. SWD’s staff will also
explain this policy to those who have questions regarding this arrangement.
